This classification is used because the dataset they developed contains a query for each question to determine the answer. The first categorization is the number of triple patterns required to query the answer. The second category is the shape of the required query. The third SPARQL category is intended to provide an understanding of the complexity of the query. This is achieved by identifying the components necessary for query formulation, such as SELECT, ASK, DESCRIBE, COUNT, etc.

title: Divide and Conquer the EmpiRE: A Community-Maintainable Knowledge Graph of Empirical Research in Requirements Engineering
note: The paper did not provide a taxonomy of question types in their paper but rather a list of questions in their replication package. We looked at those questions and categorized them into the types mentioned below.

types.description: For example: How has the reporting of threats to validity evolved over time?
For example: What types of threats to validity do the authors report?
For example: How many different empirical methods are used per publication?

title: Writing good software engineering research papers
info: The paper has later been reviewed in 'Software Engineering Research at the International Conference on Software Engineering in 2016' by Allam et al. who confirm the current relevance of the paper.

types.description: Has an emphasis on how a software problem is solved. The focus is on methods of development or analysis that enhance productivity, quality, or automation.
Focused on methods that evaluate software approaches, tools, or technologies.

types.type: Design, Evaluation, or Analysis of a particular Instance
types.description: Are concerned with a certain instance that may be a particular system, practice, design or other instance of a system or method. The purpose of these questions is to evaluate or contrast the efficiency or performance of the mentioned instance or various instances.
Seek to define or understand broad concepts or systems in Software Engineering by asking for definitions, taxonomies, or general principles.

Focuses on approaches that deal with a specific problem in a new way. Because these approaches address innovative or theoretical aspects, the questions ask for either an affirmative or a negative answer toward the feasibility or existence of a certain approach.

Given a question, the expected result is a concept for implementation, representation, management, or analysis. The answer of a procedure or technique should be practical, providing actionable steps or new methodologies.

Insights that provide structure or taxonomy for a given problem area. This includes architectural styles, frameworks, design patterns, non-formal domain analysis, well-grounded checklists, well-argued informal generalizations, guidance for integrating other results, and well-organized interesting observations.
Based on observed data that often uses statistical or observational analysis to validate its conclusions.
Formal meaning that it is often mathematically defined to allow for a formal analysis or automatic manipulation.
The asking point concerns a specific software tool that embodies a technique or a formal language that should have a calculus, semantics, or other basis for computing or inference.

The solution must adhere to Software Engineering principles and can take the form of a design, a prototype, or a complete implementation. The answer could also involve a thorough analysis of a system or its development.
Interesting insights or general guidelines are provided in a report. The authors mention that the answer is not general or systematic enough to be categorized as a descriptive model.

title: Selecting Empirical Methods for Software Engineering Research

types.description: Explore the existence of a phenomena for example: Does X exist?
Address characteristics or classifications for instance: What are the properties of X?
Intent to investigate similarities and differences between two or more phenomena, for example: How does X differ from Y?
Relates to questions that seek to quantify the phenomenon. For example How often does X occur? or What is the average amount of X?
Ask about describing the functionality of a process. For instance: How does X normally work? or What are the steps X goes through as it evolves?
Asks if one factor affects another, for example: Does X cause Y? or Does X prevent Y?.
Investigates relationships between different causes: Does X cause more Y than does Z?
Examines how context affects a cause-effect relationship.
Discovering improved methods for software design. For example: What is an effective way to achieve X? or What strategies help to achieve X?

title: LC-QuAD 2.0: A Large Dataset for Complex Question Answering over Wikidata and Dbpedia

types.description: If the question requires a single fact to be retrieved.
If the question requires a single fact to be retrieved and imposes an additional type constraint.
If the question requires multiple facts to be retrieved.

Special type related to the Wikidata KG. The term qualifiers refers to special property type used in a Wikidata graph to add further details to a triple. See: https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Help:Qualifiers
Questions with two separate but related intentions that could be split into two kinds of questions.
Expects a "Yes" or a "No" as an answer.
Questions that require counting facts within the graph and further aggregation of these counts.
Involves performing operations on strings related to the facts of the graph, such as matching or filtering with string patterns.
Includes time requirements such as dates or timed events.
Questions that require counting facts within the graph.

title: A Non-Factoid Question-Answering Taxonomy

types.description: You want to understand the procedure/method of doing/achieving something. The expected answer structure are Instructions/guidelines provided in a step-by-step manner. Example patterns are: How to ...? How can I do . . . ? What is the process for . . . ? What is the best way to . . . ?

You want to find out reasons of/for something. The answer expects a list of reasons with evidence. Example patterns are: Why does . . . ? What is the reason for . . . ? What causes . . . ? How come ... happened?

You want to learn about the features/description/definition of a concept/idea/object/event. The answer expects Wikipedia-like passage describing/defining an event/object or its properties based only on facts. Example patterns are: What is . . . ? How does/do . . . work? What are the properties of . . . ? What is the meaning of . . . ? How do you describe . . . ?

You want to compare/contrast two or more things, understand their differences/similarities. The answer expects A list of key differences and/or similarities of something compared to another thing. Example patterns are: How is X . . . to/from Y? What are the . . . of X over Y? How does X . . . against Y?

You want to get advice or recommendations on a particular topic. The answer expects Advantages, disadvantages, and main features of an entity (product, event, person, etc) summarised from personal experiences. Example patterns are: Would you recommend . . . ? How do you like . . . ? What do you think about . . . ? Should I . . . ?

You want to debate on a hypothetical question (is someone right or wrong, is some event perceived positively or negatively?). The answer expects Arguments on a debatable topic consisting of different opinions on something supported or weakened by pros and cons of the topic in the question. Example patterns are: Does . . . exist? Can . . . be successful? Do you think . . . are . . . ? Is . . . really a . . . ?

title: Question Answering on Scholarly Knowledge Graphs

types.description: Involves questions that need to aggregate information, for example, to infer the minimum, average, or most common of something.
Expects a 'Yes' or a 'No' as an answer.
Combination of information that requires multiple facts from the graph to collect the answer to the question
Requires only one fact from the graph.
Related to queries that list elements of information from the graph

title: Construction of Design Science Research Questions

types.description: Identifying certain kinds of problems and to build solution artifacts to address these.
Focuses on identifying a gap in the literature and suggest an artifact to bridge it.
Indicates deficiencies in current theories that require additional research to address these issues.
Defines the issue being addressed. This could be a research challenge, gap, problem, opportunity, or a specific requirement.
Whether a publication has used research questions at all.
Categorizes broad types related to the design process, product, knowledge or other types.
Defines the goal of the research question. This can be exploratory, prescriptive, constructive, confirmatory, explanatory, or descriptive.
Defines the activities required for the question. This can be developmental, evaluative, or a mix of both.
Concerns theoretical statements that support the research approach. This is categorized into no specific theory, kernel theory, formal theory, or testable theory.

Encompasses categories such as instantiation, model, construct, and method. Additionally, it incorporates mixed categories, such as model combined with instantiation, and another combination consisting of construct, model, and instantiation.

title: The question answering systems: A survey

types.description: The focus of a question has been defined by Moldovan et al. to be a word or sequence of words which indicate what information is being asked for in the question.

In order to correctly answer a question, it is required to understand what type of information the question asks for, because knowing the type of a question can provide constraints on what constitutes relevant data (the answer), which helps other modules to correctly locate and verify an answer.

Answer type classification is a subsequent and related component to question classification. It is based on a mapping of the question classification. Once a question has been classified, a simple rule based mapping would be used to determine the potential answer types. Again, because question classification can be ambiguous, the system should allow for multiple answer types.

title: A Taxonomy for Classifying Questions Asked in Social Question and Answering

types.description: The intent of an accuracy question is to receive answers based on some factual or prescriptive knowledge. The purpose of it is to receive one or more correct answers, instead of responses based on the answerer’s personal experience. This type of questions usually looks for facts, definitions, and prescriptive methods on how to do something.

The intent of a social question is to request for either companionship or coordination from others. It includes questions searching for someone who share the same agendas or someone who can provide physical or emotional assistance.

The intent of a knowledge question is to receive responses reflecting the answerer’s personal opinions, advices, preferences, or experiences. It is usually with a “survey” purpose, which encourages the audience to provide their personal answers.
The conversational tweet is usually with social or conversational purpose, and does not convey any real information need.

title: The Structure and Performance of an Open-Domain Question Answering System
note: The taxonomy of this paper includes many classifications with the 'wh-' words. We decided against such a classification as our taxonomy should be more focused towards the meaning, intention and complexity of the question and less on the structure of the questions themselves. In our opinion, to focus on the structure of question was more important before the advent of LLMs, but now it is less important to classify the structure of the question.

title: Types of research questions: descriptive, predictive, or causal

types.description: Descriptive questions seek to describe the landscape, to provide an overview of the situation. These types of questions use data to provide a quantitative summary of certain features of the world.

Predictive questions help readers form expectations about what is likely to happen in the future. The aim is to learn something about the future using information from the present, which requires a longitudinal study design.

Causal research questions aim to find treatment targets, identify factors that increase the risk of getting a condition or injury, or estimate what will happen to people who receive one treatment compared to another.
